title: NUJP sees union busting behind TV5 job cuts
text:
By: Ed Margareth Barahan - @inquirerdotnet INQUIRER.net / 03:01   
The National Union of Journalists of the Philippines (NUJP) on Tuesday accused TV5 of “union busting” after news reports surfaced that around 100 employees were axed on Friday. 
“We cannot but see union busting as the real motive behind the sudden retrenchment of more than a hundred of our colleagues. Of those laid off, four are union officers and 98 are union members,” NUJP said in a statement. 
Around 100 employees from the news and operations of TV5 Manila were let go, consisting of camera and field crews, drivers as well as production personnel. ADVERTISEMENT 
READ: Biz Buzz: Bloody Friday at TV5 
NUJP said that in last year’s negotiations for a Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA), the ABC Employees Union (ABCEU) had been firm in defending the rights and welfare, pushing for salary increase and benefits for its members. 
“By diminishing the number of union members, the TV5 management aims to weaken the union and replace its regular workers with contractual or agency-hired employees,” the NUJP said. 
PLDT head and CEO Manuel Pangilinan on Monday confirmed the latest wave of layoffs, saying that its television unit that has struggled to post a profit, and characterizing the event as “painful” and necessary. He also said that it is “the last of the cost-cutting situation.” 
READ: No more job cuts at TV5, says MVP 
The group said that the TV company has not shown any documents to the union to prove its claim that it is losing money. 
It added that the network has ”trampled on the dignity of its long-time employees as workers,” many of whom had been working for the company for more than 10 years already. 
“A perfunctory call from TV5’s HR Department, a severance check, and the way out the door were how the workers learned of the news of their sacking. They were then barred from entering the state of the art broadcast center building they helped build with their blood, sweat and tears,” the NUJP said. 
Unfortunately, the trouble of TV5 workers is not isolated. 
“The entire media industry is full of un-unionized workers who suffer long working hours without security of tenure, just pay and benefits,” the group said. 
“As we pledge our solidarity and support to our ABCEU colleagues, we also call on all journalists to unite and unionize for media workers’ rights and welfare,” it added. JE
